data.title: RPM package has incomplete list of dependencies
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: CentOS 7.3 (x64)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install CentOS 7.3 minimal ISO to a new VM
2. sudo yum install code-1.8.1-1482158209.el7.x86_64.rpm
3. code .

Expected:
VS Code to start

Actual:
VS Code crashes, saying it cannot find libgtk-2.0.so
I then manually installed the "gtk2" rpm to meet the missing dependency.

VS Code still crashes, saying it cannot find libXtst.so.
I installed the "libXtst" rpm

VS Code still crashes, saying it cannot find libgconf-2.0.so
I installed the "GConf2" rpm

VS Code starts, but immediately and silently exits. Running with the --verbose option eventually points to a failure to locate a "sans" font.

I installed the "gnu-free-sans-fonts" rpm
VS Code successfully starts and is operational.

So it seems like the above 4 packages should be added as package dependencies, to avoid the user having to manually find/install additional packages.

data.title: Test: Go To Implementation
Test: Markdown Preview Editor Selection Scrolling
data.body:
- [x] Any OS @joaomoreno
- [x] Any OS @sandy081 

Complexity: 2

1. Clone and open the VSCode-docs repo: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs
1. Open a markdown file.
1. Select a header somewhere in the middle of the file
1. Open the markdown preview
    -  ⭐️ The preview should scroll so that the selected header is near the top of the page and marked with a light blue line to the left side.
1. Hover the mouse various paragraphs in the preview.
    -  ⭐️ A dark blue line should be shown next to top level paragraphs and images in the preview when the mouse is over it.
1. Double click somewhere in the markdown preview
    -  ⭐️ This should switch to the editor at the clicked line.
1. Move the preview to the side so that both it and the editor are showing.
1. Move the selection in the editor about
    -  ⭐️ As the selection is moved, the light blue marker should update to mark the top level block element of the selection.
    -  ⭐️ The preview should also scroll so that the selected line element is about a quarter of the way down from the top of the page.
1. Try typing some text in the editor.
    -  ⭐️ The preview content should update and remain in the same scroll position.
1. Disable the setting `markdown.preview.scrollPreviewWithEditorSelection`
    -  ⭐️ When the selection is moved, the preview should no longer update it position.

data.title: [FileWatcher] failed to start after retrying for some time, giving up. Please report this as a bug report!e.onUnexpectedError @ shell.ts:541 ipc.cp.ts:175IPC "Watcher" crashed with exit code null
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:

Version 1.8.1
Commit ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281
Date 2016-12-19T14:41:20.664Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0

- OS Version:

Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Get the Linux kernel source code
2. Open it in Visual Studio Code
3. Observe "Error: Extension host terminated unexpectedly. Please reload the window to recover."
4. Click "Reload"
5. While not giving up, goto 3
6. Toggle Developer tools and check for errors
7. Find the message "shell.ts:541[FileWatcher] failed to start after retrying for some time, giving up. Please report this as a bug report!e.onUnexpectedError @ shell.ts:541
ipc.cp.ts:175IPC "Watcher" crashed with exit code null"


So, I'm reporting it as a bug as requested :wink:. I'm guessing this has to do with the fact that the Linux kernel source code has a very large number of source code files that are all trying to be watched.

data.title: Test: Markdown Preview -> Editor Scroll Sync
data.body:
- [x] Any OS @mousetraps 
- [x] Any OS @alexandrudima 

Complexity: 2

1. Clone and open the VSCode-docs repo: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs
1. Open a markdown file.
1. Preview the file 
1. Scroll the markdown preview and scroll around. (on top of the editor, not to the side)
1. Switch back to editor
    -  ⭐️ The editor should not have been scrolled.
1. Move the preview to a side tab so that both it and the editor are showing.
1. Scroll the preview
    -  ⭐️ When the preview is scrolled, the top of the editor is synchronized with the top of the preview. Make sure to scroll over images and other elements to check correct mapping
1. Open a second editor so that you have three tabs: two editors and a preview
    -  ⭐️ The preview should scroll both editor now. Also check this in horizontal layout mode and with line wrapping off.
1. Disable the setting `markdown.preview.scrollEditorWithPreview` and try scrolling the preview again
    - ⭐️ The scroll sync should no longer be enabled.

Steps:
1. Open files whose language has indentation rules set, for example [TypeScript](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/typescript/src/typescriptMain.ts#L193) and [Ruby](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/ruby/src/rubyMain.ts#L12).
2. Try to write code that matches existing patterns and make sure the indentation adjusts correctly when pressing enter.

Helpful links:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17868 describes the meaning of four indentation rules and how we interpret them.

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Telemetry for http/s links
Test: Emmet profile, preferences and snippets from external files
data.body:
Testing #11679 - [x] Any OS @stevencl - [x] Any OS @chrmarti Complexity: 3 Helpful links: - [Emmet CheetSheet](http://docs.emmet.io/cheat-sheet/) - [Emmet Customization](http://docs.emmet.io/customization/) Clear all emmet related settings. - Try emmet abbreviations expansions in an html file. (type any html element and hit tab: div => `
` a => ``) - Html elements that do not have closing tags (like `br`, `hr`, `input`, `img`) expand just to a single tag like `
`, `
`, ``, `` - Abbreviations like `.title` would expand to `
` - Try emmet abbreviations expansions in a css file. Check out the CSS part of [Emmet CheetSheet](http://docs.emmet.io/cheat-sheet/) (m10 would expand to "margin": 10px, c#1c would expand to "color: #1c1c1c) Settings from external files: - Create a folder anywhere. Create the below 3 files in this folder - `syntaxProfiles.json` with content: `{"html":"xhtml"}` - `preferences.json` with content: `{"css.color.case": "upper", "css.intUnit": "pt" }` - `snippets.json` with content: ``` { "html": { "abbreviations": { "a": "" } } } ``` - add setting `emmet.extensionsPath` with value as absolute path to this folder. Now repeat your previous emmet expansions with html and css. The settings from the 3 json files would be loaded and you will see the below differences - HTML elements that do not have closing tags, now get a self closing tag. Eg: `
`, `` etc. This is due to the `syntaxProfiles.json` - The abbreviation `a` that would previously expand to ``, now expands to ``. This is due to the `snippets.json` - The CSS abbreviation `m10` now expands and use `pt` instead of `px`. And `c#1c` when expanded has upper case. This is due to `preferences.json`. Add the below to your settings file. ``` "emmet.syntaxProfiles": { "html": { "attr_quotes": "single" } }, "emmet.preferences": { "css.color.case": "lower" } ``` Now repeat your previous emmet expansions with html and css. The User/Workspace settings should override the settings from the external files and you would see the below differences: - HTML elements that do not have closing tags are back to the old behaviour of not getting self closing tags - `.title` now expands with single quotes for attributes instead of double - In CSS file, `c#1C` and `c#1c` both will get expanded with lower case Note: - Changes in User/Workspace settings should get reflected without VS Code reload. - Changes to the external files will get reflected only on VS Code reload. - `~` not supported in `emmets.extensionsPath` at the moment

data.title: Terminal doesn't honor quoted command lines.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

The [vscode-java](https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-java) project would like to get rid of its (badly) forked [language-configuration.json](https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-java/blob/1c3a5c25d382c1cbcac0f8038d8b1b5231454784/language-configuration.json) and thus requests adding javadoc autoclose settings back to the default java language configuration.

This is related to https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-java/issues/144

2. make window narrow so that the settings editor has to wrap

data.title: Test terminal performance and Windows support improvements
data.body:
Testing #13625, #17875

- [x] Linux @roblourens 
- [x] OSX @bpasero 
- [x] Windows @dbaeumer 

Complexity: 4 (ideally someone fairly familiar with terminals and curses apps)

Much of the terminal frontend xterm.js was rewritten for performance this version, here is a summary of what happened:

- The parser was rewritten for performance
- A catch up mechanism was added which utilizes XOFF/XON signals to tell the pty process to stop while the parser and renderer catch up
- Rendering is now done asynchronously in an animation frame callback
- Additional frame skipping was added to prevent printing to the viewport when the result would change 20ms later anyway
- A circular list is now used to manage the buffer, promoting memory reuse, reducing GCs and automatically handling trimming of the buffer to conform with the scrollback value (amount of lines kept in the buffer)
- General rendering performance improvements

Additionally on Windows the library used to simulate pseudoterminals has been upgraded several versions and cleaned up which was a huge change that should fix many bugs such as:

- Arrow keys wording in Bash on Windows https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10163
- Git Bash, Bash on Windows prompt and other shells having their prompt getting out of sync when using backspace https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7345
- Prompt screwing up when using tab https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16914
- Many other issues https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14613

As a result a fairly broad test would be ideal. Here are some areas to focus on:

- Running commands that generate a lot of output, I used `ls -lR` extensively to test during development
- Applications such as less, vim, nano, git, etc. act as expected
- The scroll bar accurately represents the current viewport
- The terminal behaves when the terminal buffer is not full (new terminal) and full (buffer length = scrollback)
- Test with different shells
  - Linux/OSX: bash, zsh
  - Windows: cmd, powershell, Git Bash, Bash on Windows (may require Windows Insiders)

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Consolidate under single 'welcome' folder
data.body: Testing #18091

data.title: Feature request: Make font style independent of color theme
data.body:
Today, the entire style of tokens is left to the mercy of the color theme.

That means that you might, like me, find the perfect _color_ combination, but the theme doesn't render keywords bold and it renders comments without italics. In other words, there are permutations of settings that aren't solved by the one-size-fits-all approach of today.

The only way to fix is to fork the theme and edit it, which shouldn't be necessary. For example, if I release my forked theme, then I'm forcing all users to accept italic comments, but this might be the one detail that isn't to their liking. This further leads to a proliferation of themes that make just minor changes to other themes.

To me, "color theme" does not imply something that should control how tokens are styled. In particular, I'd love to be able to tweak the font sizes of individual keywords.

As an aside, there's considerable inconsistency in themes. If I enable "Solarized Dark" (one of the few themes that uses bold styling), some languages (JavaScript) will render bold keywords, whereas others (Go) will not. What's the explanation for this?

Test plan item for PR #17698, which implements #16771

data.title: Add option to turn off fast rendered view line
Test FastRenderedViewLine
data.body:
I am sorry for the long list below, but this is the test matrix of that code and I've noticed things are different on each configuration:
- [x] VSCode Linux @aeschli 
- [x] VSCode Windows 7 @bpasero 
- [x] VSCode Windows 8 @jrieken 
- [x] VSCode Windows 10 @chrmarti 
- [x] VSCode Mac @joaomoreno
- [x] standalone editor IE11 @egamma
- [x] standalone editor Edge @Tyriar 
- [x] standalone editor FF on Windows @dbaeumer 
- [x] standalone editor FF on Mac @weinand 
- [x] standalone editor FF on Linux @isidorn 
- [x] standalone editor Safari @kieferrm

Complexity: 2 (it involves mostly looking / making selections in the editor but this explanation is long so giving it a 2)

---

There is a new type of rendered view line in the editor.


A rendered view line is used to reply to queries of the type:
* at what px offset is a column rendered, (e.g. rendering decorations, cursor position, selection, etc.)
* what column sits at a px offset (i.e. hit-testing with the mouse).


The new `FastRenderedViewLine` is used (dynamically) under the following conditions:
* the font you are using is monospace for regular ASCII characters (in the range 32-126), (including for · and →)
* a line contains only regular ASCII characters (in the range 32-126) or `\t`
* a line does not contain any before/after decorations (such as those added by CSS color boxes)


The new `FastRenderedViewLine` does not ask the DOM for column -> px offset transformations, but simply computes the results using basic math. This has a considerable speed advantage, as the browser is not forced to do a synchronous layout, but the results may be wrong if our assumptions don't hold true. 

**This perf improvement is important because most of our users use a monospace font and most of the source code is regular ASCII + tabs. It also gives us some breathing room in the time it takes to paint a frame, that could be later used for fancy features as a minimap**

---

### standalone editor setup
* clone https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor next to vscode
* `monaco-editor` and `vscode` should be sibling folders
* run `gulp watch` as usual in `vscode`
* run `npm install .` in `monaco-editor`
* open `monaco-editor/test/index.html` in a browser (file protocol will do)
* click on `dev` next to monaco-editor the url should now contain `?editor=dev`
* To change a font in the standalone editor, edit the file index.html such that you pass a font familiy to the editor, e.g `fontFamily: "arial"`

---

### Check "exception cases":
Check that the cursor is correctly rendered in between characters in any of the following 3 cases:
* configure a font family such as Arial.
* have on a line some text that is outside the regular ASCII chars (e.g. an emoji, ü, CJK text, Hebrew text).
* go to a line in a CSS file that uses color boxes.

### Test that `FastRenderedViewLine` is correct:
* configure a font family that is monospace (or leave our default)
* have a line that is at least ~100 chars of regular ASCII (100 chars such that rounding errors begin to show)
* avoid CSS color boxes (i.e. use a different language)

Please check:
* that you can change `window.zoomLevel` (in standalone editor browser zoom).
* start without a zoom level, zoom in, zoom out.
* start with a zoom level, reset zoom, etc.
* change the font size, change the font family dynamically
* in all these cases the cursor should not appear to be off.

---

e.g. what an "off" cursor looks like:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/22214248/5350d692-e197-11e6-8e82-1e4bce335002.png)

data.title: Test language specific settings #1587
data.body:
Test for #1587 

- [x] Windows OS @dbaeumer 
- [x] any OS @mjbvz 

Complexity: 3

Now you can configure editor settings for a language mode. You can configure it either

- When you are selecting a language mode, by clicking the language in the status bar when a file is opened and selecting Configure settings for the language
- Or use a global command `Configure language specific settings...` where you can select a language and configure settings for the language 

Above actions opens the User settings file and inserts the language identifier key. Use intelli-sense and add/override settings. Test that these settings are applied only to those files whose associated language is the one you overridden settings for.

Example: In User Settings
```json
"editor.lineNumbers": "off"
"[json]": {
   "editor.lineNumbers": "relative"
}
```
Above settings will not display line numbers for all files except for `json` files which display relative line numbers.

You can also configure language based settings in workspace settings. This will override respective language based settings in user settings.

Example: In Workspace Settings
```json
"[json]": {
   "editor.lineNumbers": "on"
}
```
Above settings will display line numbers normally for `json` files

All `editor.*`, `diffEditor.*` and some `files.*` settings are allowed to override. These will be shown by intelli-sense. Try to configure them for different languages in user and workspace settings and test that these are getting applied correctly (workspace settings always override user settings).

data.title: Test User/Workspace Settings Improvements #18094
data.body:
Test for #18094

- [x] any OS @alexandrudima 
- [x] any OS @ramya-rao-a 

Complexity : 3

Test this by verifying following. Once verified, please mark them as verified so that they wont appear in verification list.

data.title: Test improved multicursor actions experience
data.body:
- [x] any OS @egamma - [x] any OS @kieferrm Complexity: 2 Test item for #18973 The following actions: | Label | Default Keybinding | |---|---| | Add Selection To Next Find Match | Ctrl+D
Cmd+D (Mac) | | Move Last Selection To Next Find Match | Ctrl+K,Ctrl+D
Cmd+K,Cmd+D (Mac) | | Add Selection To Previous Find Match | - | | Move Last Selection To Previous Find Match | - | | Select All Occurrences of Find Match | Ctrl+Shift+L
Cmd+Shift+L (Mac) | | Change All Occurrences | Ctrl+F2
Cmd+F2 (Mac) | **change their behaviour based on the find input state even if the find widget is hidden**: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/22174179/50a696ae-dfd8-11e6-8a54-4042ad1b1e05.png) Moreover, the two toggles can be changed via keybindings **even when the find widget is hidden**: | Option | Default keybinding | |---|---| | `Match Case` | Alt+C
Cmd+Alt+C (Mac) | | `Match Whole Word` | Alt+W
Cmd+Alt+W (Mac) | --- Please test that: ### The find widget options (when the find widget is shown) now briefly flash when executing these actions to let you know that they are an input ### The find widget options appear by themselves briefly when executing these actions (including toggling via keyboard) * they show up by themselves * you can interact with the mouse with them * you can hover and learn about the keybindings * they track the exact same state as the find widget options.
